comments.commentBody:
You know nothing about financing in higher education. First, federal supports to the states have been slashed because of Bush 43's Great Recession, resulting in not only increased unemployment for teachers, policemen and firefighters, since states cannot, politically, step up to make the difference. The easiest scapegoat in every state has been support for public universities--once state supported, then state assisted, then state existing, and now state inhibited.

Did you know that it is illegal to mingle instructional and research funding sources, on every campus? Or did you think that federal research funds could be used for classroom instruction?

Budgets everywhere have been cut, first across the board, then by eliminating programs. U. Florida just eliminated computer science, in spite of an increasing demand for graduates, after FL cut their budget by 30% over the last 6 years. The only recourse left is to raise tuition as carefully as possible, while seeking private support for scholarships, etc., to mitigate that.

Two flagship public universities with which I am familiar have their state operating budgets now down to about 10%, and their total budgets below 5%, from state sources. If the state would just deed them their (incredibly valuable) physical plants and leave them alone, they would thrive, the state troglodytes would have one fewer thing to complain about, and you would shut up.
Yes, it is all about sales and figures.

http://outlookindia.com/article.aspx?280608
In implementing Hindutva, nobody outdoes Narendra Modi. He sparked off the state-aided slaughter of Muslims a decade ago, but now tries to balance his karma by conducting dental and cataract surgeries for cows.

While Muslim victims of the Gujarat riots still languish in relief camps, Modi gloats that no cow has to travel more than three kilometres to reach a health camp. In this animal farm, Her Holiness Mother Cow is a first-class citizen with health insurance and a pension plan. Dalits, Adivasis, Muslims and Christians, being beef-eating minorities, cannot press for similar privileges.

http://outlookindia.com/article.aspx?280072
Prime Minister aspirant and Gujarat chief minister Narendra Modi is fond of quoting Swami Vivekananda.

For an astute and ambitious man, well-studied in puritan ideological, intellectual and moral schools throughout his life, Modi would know what the truth of Gujarat 2002 carnage is, and why it hurts.

That truth is around Modi; he refuses to acknowledge it.

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/parvez-ahmed/the-extreme-makeover-of-i_b_1...
The Indian national motto succinctly states, Satyameva Jayate -- Truth Stands Invincible.
Very noble. Yes,  justice will not be denied, and will finally prevail.

http://www.openthemagazine.com/article/voices/why-is-narendrabhai-afraid...
The claim goes Narendra Modi is ‘incorruptible’. This is only an exercise in rhetoric.

It is strange to claim incorruptibility for a man who refuses to let any of his actions be subject to the normal checks and balances of democratic governance.

The simple fact: Modi is a failure on his own terms.

http://www.livemint.com/2012/02/29202235/Incredible-impunity.html
Of all the potential and credible contenders to be the next prime minister, the least deserving candidate is Narendra Modi.
http://www.rediff.com/news/report/us-congressman-campaigns-for-us-visa-f...

Its about time that Muslims of India are treated equal in all respects of modern life in India. Millions of Muslim women are treated as second class citizens in their own country because of the perceived threat of secularization of their Sharia beliefs. Its time Muslims speak about it themselves to redeem their right and dignity as equal citizens.

Clearly, the clerics are in favor of this bizarre law because almost always the clerics offer themselves as the 'temporary husband' who consummates the marriage before handing back the woman to her husband.
No wonder there's a line of students at Madrassahs training to become clerics. This is one of the key perks of the job.

So, this is the best we can do? Are we near the breakdown of healthcare system, until something intolerable ignites a true reform?

Our organizations, especially those with greater influence or power, are constantly trying to make things more complicated so people don't understand and have no means to fight back. The processes become so complicated that many companies are created just to service each other, to outsource endlessly.

Organizations exist for reasons. What are the real reasons these organizations exist? No wonder in the healthcare industry many businesses are formed to get into this market as it is too lucrative.

Why do hospitals have a glut of unpaid bills? Now hospitals can charge whatever they want, without the agreement from the patients. There's not contract between hospitals and patients. What is the ancient contract between doctors and patients? Medical school course 101?

The US market-style healthcare system is proven that it does not work --- for patients. It works for for-profit organizations (in name or in reality). Everybody has become miser.

This is the best we can do, in this exceptional country in the history of human beings! Truly exceptional.

You seem unable to read between the lines. It's the government that investigated the fraud on government projects. The over billling was undoubtedly common to their private jobs, whereas the minority issue was not. And government work was a small per cent of their work.
This is classic one-percentism.    They're allowed to go on an unregulated stealing spree and  then pay a fee to avoid criminal charges.  Note how the victims are generally government agencies.

Why not attempt to solve the problem as follows: before a woman agrees to marry someone, she should first require her prospective;mate to enter into a pre-nuptual agreement in which she would lay out protections for herself in the event that she becomes divorced.......without consideration of fault.....period.....that's the end of it!

If the religious or secular authorities were subsequently to take the position that such an agreement is void or unenforceable, then the issue would be drawn for a full public debate.

This could be the principle around which a women's movement could rally.

I saw it on April 23. I thought it was very good, and especially liked Linda Lavin and Dick Latessa (although I would like to have seen more of Mr. Latessa).

As I was thinking about it while walking home I realized there seemed to me to have been an imbalance in the play. I felt like it had come up short in terms of delineation of Mr. & Mrs. Lyons and their relationship, while going overboard on their son (and I thought the scene stuck in the middle at the empty apartment was way overdone). I guess, based on what I had heard and read about the play earlier, I was expecting "The Ultimate Dysfunctional Family Play," or perhaps "The Ultimate Jewish Mother Play," but it seemed to me more like "The Ultimate Long-Suffering Gay Son of a Jewish Mother Play," with most of the emphasis on the son.
As a matter of fact, yes. Apostasy in Islam can lead to a death sentence.

It looks like the patriarchy might have painted themselves into a corner on this one... she will have to,er, *consummate* with another man, legally. And it is REQUIRED. Would her lawyer suggest she videotape it in case the authorities requested proof? And then the *gentleman* has to mix up and serve the Triple Taraq to her, which he MIGHT NOT DO!!! :).

Why not divorce the religion? What are they gonna do? Kill you? :)

I have rarely seen a play in such bad taste. The obnoxious members of the dysfunctional family represented every horrible stereotype --particularly of the Jewish wife and mother. Yes, it was well acted, and yes, there were funny lines...but the totality is depressing and I think, anti-Semitic. These people were completely one-dimensional--awful.

Lavin is the best (maybe only) reason to see this play. She has some hilarious one liners. But what is it all for? The second act was actually stronger than the first, but it was in such stark contrast to the tone and style of the first act that it did n't even feel like it was from the same play. Felt like the playwright didn't know what play s he wanted to write. The most upsetting thing is that this play somehow managed to transfer to broadway while much better plays like Sons of the Prophet and 4000 Miles have not. Too bad.

If you are a fan of Linda Lavin, you will love the show.  She is wonderful, but again another Linda Lavin production getting the same laughs she always gets.  The same goes for her performance in Other Desert Cities.  The audience loved her and the play, but I was somewhat bored plus I don't really like so much negativity in life especially in hospital rooms.

This musical is superb! It is not perfect in every way, but it possesses all of the qualities you would expect from a "god old-fashioned" modern musical. The cast is superb and the directing/choreography is some of the best Ms. Marshall has ever produced. See this show! Regardless of what a certain reviewer might have to say, you won't be sorry.

I thought he and Kelli Ohara would be a perfect pair though Matthew is good and will get even better.  S'wonderful fun.  Superb choreography.  Judy Kaye and Michael McGrath are great.  And it's Gershwin.

I eagerly anticipated both Nice Work If You Can Get It and Porgy and Bess; the chance to hear full evenings of Gershwin music peformed live has become quite rare, even in NYC.

Once again, I was disappointed with the results.

Porgy and Bess, despite the efforts of the creative team, still featured a strong cast and the main musical moments still soared. Nice Work If You Can Get It, however, committs the more egregious sin of shoehorning some of Gershwin's best songs into a lifeless plot to be performed by a cast at least 10 years too old for the roles they play. (Kelli O'Hara is the only exception and her singing is lovely.) However the majority of the songs are ill-served due to bad staging and insufficient singing. I would rather have seen Porgy and Bess a second time than Nice Work If You Can Get It once.

The government of India, as usual, will have to make a cynical political calculation: Refuse to accede to the women's request and keep conservative Muslim happy, or concede to the women's demands and annoy the men.  I am betting on the former. Patriarchy and Islam go hand in hand, and the Government will not do anything to annoy Muslim men as they have the power with Muslim women, poor weak creatures who continuously have to fight for their rights with both hands tied behind the back with the Koran allowing four marriages.
The Sharia war on women is a problem across much of the world and getting worse.  Women need to use all the power they have to achieve equality and men need to support them in this fight.

Sharia is, Muslims are not. It's a difference and distinction many Southerners fail to make. (I have spoken to both Southerners and southern Imans and southern Muslims, including an Iman once in charge of a mosque a mile from Bob Jones University.)

Funny that this same fear expressed by Southerners in the United States are diminished by liberals as bigotry and small mindedness. Sharia is evil; both Muslims and non-Muslims should fear it - no ifs and buts.

This shows the fundamental problem with pandering to the prelates - no matter what the religion. A secular country needs to have uniform laws irrespective of what religion one happens to be born into.

Actually that's not true. In fact there is a Sharia Board that is a nationwide committee of Maulvis (Muslim Scholars, which is again an elected body) who make the decision about what is acceptable for Muslims throughout India. Of course this is also not entirely true for all Muslims because there are several sects of Muslims residing in different parts of India. They are not a monolith as it is commonly perceived.

Also, to understand the reason India grants its Muslim population Sharia type of "freedom", you have to delve into its history, which cant be done here. But you have to start from the formation of Muslim league of India in the first half of 20th Century when they started demanding a separate state called Pakistan. Therefore to assure Muslim's religious freedom in will be respected in the newly free India several concession were made and Sharia was one of them. However, with 65 years of democracy its about time that Muslims in India demand more from their country in terms of civil liberties.

Although one should be careful in parsing articles describing foreign cultures, this is relevant to the gay marriage debate in the US.

It appears that the Indian state has for all intents and purposes removed itself from Muslim marriages, with the predictable effect that the unelected local religious leaders come up with widely varying rulings. A bit of a warning example for those who think the state should entirely remove itself from marriage here.

Have you ever heard of The Solar Cooker Project?
http://www.jww.org/projects/ontheground/sudan/solar-cooker-project

For more information about the Solar Cooker Project, please contact: Rachel Andres, Director, Solar Cooker Project
Email: rachel@jww.org
Phone: 818-501-1836 ext. 250

The article is missing a few important words.

POORLY ENGINEERED cook stoves may not be having the expected positive effect.

It's counter intuitive, but these "simple" stoves do in fact require quite a bit of skill to develop so that they achieve their goals: be long lasting, embraced by users, intuitive to use, and effectively reduce emissions.

Successful stoves are in development and are undergoing field testing by several fine groups - and I firmly believe they make a difference.
